topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 1.1: Backup and Restore the HLM VM and MySQL Cluster

body.p: This page explains how to backup and restore the HLM VM in the event of catastrophic failure. The page also explains how to recover the Percona XtraDB cluster on the cloud controllers in the event of a database corruption.

The HPE Helion OpenStack cloud installation provides highly optimized MySQL databases inside of the HPE Helion Public Cloud. A MySQL node is installed on each of the three controller nodes in the non-KVM region. The installation also includes the Percona XtraDB application, which takes care of synchronization of the data between nodes if one of the nodes goes down and comes back later. You can use Percona XtraDB to backup and restore the MySQL nodes.

section.title: When to Backup the HLM VM
section.p: You should create a backup from HLM VM as follows:

ul.li: when the HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade installation is complete,
when any change is made to the HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade components,
after synching the files on the HLM VM. The files should be synced periodically using a tool appropriate for your environment.

section.title: When to Restore the HLM VM
section.p: You should restore the HLM VM if there are any issues with the HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade components, for example:

ul.li: there is any problem with a VM;
there is any problem in the operating system level;
there is any problem with the installation that cannot be corrected.

section.p: Important: During the restore process the original HLM VM will be deleted from the KVM Host.

section.title: Backing up the HLM VM
section.p: To back up the HLM VM, use the following steps:

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager host.
Backup the /root/infra-ansible-playbooks folder by copying the folders to a remote system. This will backup the group_vars folder used to create the HLM VM.

Backup the following folders to a remote system:
/root - This backs up all the source code, packages, hlinux netboot as well as cloud folders
/opt - This backs up all the installed code/configuration and also h* scripts
/var/log/hlm - This backs up all generated log files
/root/.ssh - This backs up ssh keys generated per cloud used to access cloud nodes

section.title: Restore the HLM VM
section.p: To restore the HLM VM, use the following steps:

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager host.
Copy the /root/infra-ansible-playbooks folder from the backup location to the lifecycle manager host.
Re-create the HLM VM by executing from /root/infra-ansible-playbooks folder: ansible-playbook -i hosts setup_hlm_onBM.yml
Log in to the HLM VM.

Copy the following files from the backup folder to the same location on the HLM VM:
/root
/opt
/var/log/hlm
/root/.ssh

section.title: Backup and Restore the MySQL cluster
section.p: This section deals with the disaster recovery scenarios of the three node MySQL cluster (Percona XtraDB Cluster) that runs in cloud controller nodes.

If an entire cluster goes down, due to an issue (such as data corruption or MySQL defect), and the cluster does not come back up, you must restore the cluster to a previous well-known state (backup) and start the cluster from that point.
You should use to take full backups of the MySQL custer frequently, such as on a daily basis. Backing up the node on any single controller will backup the full cluster.

If the full cluster goes down or some data corruption occurs, delete the current data in all of the three nodes of MySQL and restore the backup copy on the same node from which backup was taken. Then, bootstrap the cluster and bring up rest of the nodes to synchronize the data with the recovered node of cluster.

section.title: Backing up the MySQL cluster
section.p: Use the following steps to back up the MySQL cluster:

ol.li:
Execute the following command to SSH into one of the controllers in the non-KVM region. This procedure assumes you are using Controller0: ssh <ip-address-controller0>
Where <ip-address-controller0> is the IP address of controller0 node of your environment.

Take full backup using Percona XtraBackup by running the innobackup perl script. sudo innobackupex --galera-info /backups
Where /backups is the backup location of your environment.
The script creates a timestamped folder (for example: 2013-11-06_00-00-00) that contains all backup files. The backup file contains the local node state at the time of the backup.
More info about innobackupex is at: http://www.percona.com/doc/percona-xtrabackup/2.1/innobackupex/innobackupex_option_reference.html.

Prepare the backup to be consistent. The apply-log option creates log files that the innobackupex script uses to make sure the restore works properly. sudo innobackupex --apply-log /backups/<timestamped-folder-path>
Where <timestamped-folder-path> is the path to the time-stamped folder generated in previous step.
Copy the time-stamped backup folder to a remote location.

section.title: Restore the MySQL cluster
section.p: Use the following steps to restore the MySQL cluster:

ol.li:
Stop the MySQL instance and delete the current data on all the three cluster nodes.
SSH to each controller node in the non-KVM region.
Execute the following commands:sudo /etc/init.d/mysql stop sudo rm -rf /var/lib/mysql/*
Copy the time-stamped backup folder from the remote location to any location on the controller from which you created the backup.

Perform a Percona XtraBackup recovery using the innobackupex command sudo innobackupex --copy-back /backups/<timestamped-folder-path>
Where <timestamped-folder-path> is the path to the timestamped backup folder you copied to the contoller.
Change the permissions of MySQL data folder for the MySQL user and group. sudo chown -R mysql:mysql /var/lib/mysql
Start the MySQL cluster on the controller in bootstrap mode. sudo /etc/init.d/mysql bootstrap-pxc

SSH to each of the other controllers in the non-KVM region and restart the MySQL service. sudo service mysql start
The other MySQL nodes in the cluster will automatically sync data with the restored MySQL node. When this command is complete, the MySQL cluster is fully restored to the last known .
